column1: Do all individuals with ASD have intellectual disability?
column2:
It is estimated that around 50% of persons with ASD also suffer from an intellectual disability.
Some individuals with ASD have an intellectual disability whilst some have average or above average intelligence.
Read more:
https://www.who.int/news-room/q-a-detail/autism-spectrum-disorders-(asd)

Continue asking or input 'go back' to Main Service

column1: What are the causes of Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASDs)?
column2:
The cause is unknown at present. Scientific evidence suggests that genetic, biological and environmental factors contribute to the onset of ASD by influencing early brain development. 
Some risk factors for ASD include:
1. Having a sibling with ASD.
2. Having older parents.
3. Having certain genetic conditions: people with conditions such as Down syndrome, fragile X syndrome, and Rett syndrome are more likely than others to have ASD.
Read more:
https://rockmelon.com/about-autism/

Continue asking or input 'go back' to Main Service

column1: What are the signs and symptoms of Autism?
column2:
Identifying ASD is difficult before the age of about 12 months but is generally possible by the age of 2 years. Symptoms of ASD vary from child to child. The DSM-5, the standard reference used by most healthcare providers, includes a full list of autism diagnostic criteria.
Common early signs include:  
1. Delayed speech or difficulty communicating. 
2. Poor eye contact. 
3. Little or no imaginative play. 
4. No joint attention, not looking in the same direction as others. 
5. Showing limited interest in other people. 
6. Highly emotional responses to changes in routine.  
Read more:
https://www.autism.org/is-it-autism/

Continue asking or input 'go back' to Main Service

column1: What are some of the common myths about autism?
column2:
1. Individuals on the autism spectrum avoid social contact.
2. Individuals on the autism spectrum cannot lead independent and successful lives
3. Autism is the result of bad parenting.
4. All individuals on the autism spectrum have special talent or 'savant' skills.
5. Autism can be cured.
6. People with autism do not make eye contact.
7. People with autism cannot talk.
8. Autism can be outgrown.
9. Individuals on the autism spectrum do not have feelings and thus are unable to show affection.
Read more:
https://www.autism.org.sg/living-with-autism/myths-and-facts-of-autism

Continue asking or input 'go back' to Main Service

column1: Who should I tell about the diagnosis?
column2:
Any professional involved with the adult should know that they have been diagnosed with an ASD. Sometimes, if the person is mildly affected by ASD or Asperger Syndrome, it may not be necessary to tell others. Usually, however, telling people helps them understand the person better and interact more effectively with them.
Read more:
https://www.autismontario.com/sites/default/files/2020-04/Getting%20a%20Diagnosis%20of%20ASD_0.pdf

Continue asking or input 'go back' to Main Service

column1: What progress has been made so far in autism research?
column2:
Autism research is quickly developing across many areas, including genetics, neurobiology, educational interventions, and targeted medications. One promising area of research seeks to identify autism genes in order to develop new medications based on genetic findings.
Read more:
https://icahn.mssm.edu/research/seaver/resources/autism-faqs

column1: How common is ASD?
column2:
According to recent estimates released by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): 
1. Approximately 1 in 54 children in the U.S. is diagnosed with an autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
2. 1 in 34 boys identified with autism.
3. 1 in 144 girls identified with autism.
4. Boys are 4 times more likely to be diagnosed with autism than girls.
Estimates of autism prevalence have risen steadily since the CDC began tracking the condition. What appears to be rising rates are largely due to changing definitions of autism along with expanded screenings.
Read more:
https://www.myautismteam.com/resources/autism-an-overview

Continue asking or input 'go back' to Main Service

column1: What is regressive encephalopathy?
column2:
Encephalopathy is a medical term for a disease or disorder of the brain. It usually means a slowing down of brain function. Regressive Encephalopathy means there is a disease or disorder in the brain that makes a person lose skills they once had. We know that sometimes children with mitochondrial diseases seem to be developing as they should, but around toddler or preschool age, they regress. This could be something like malnutrition, an illness such as flu, a high fever, dehydration, or it could be something else.
Read more:
https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/autism/topics.html

Continue asking or input 'go back' to Main Service

column1: Do symptoms of autism change over time?
column2:
For many children, symptoms improve with age and behavioral treatment. 
During adolescence, some children with ASD may become depressed or experience behavioral problems, and their treatment may need some modification as they transition to adulthood. People with ASD usually continue to need services and supports as they get older, but depending on severity of the disorder, people with ASD may be able to work successfully and live independently or within a supportive environment.
Read more:
https://www.ninds.nih.gov/Disorders/Patient-Caregiver-Education/Fact-Sheets/Autism-Spectrum-Disorder-Fact-Sheet#3082_5

Continue asking or input 'go back' to Main Service

column1: Speech Development in ASD?
column2:
An analysis of ARI's (Autism Research Institute) data involving 30,145 cases indicated that 9% never develop speech. Of those 91% who develop speech, 43% begin to talk by the end of their first year, 35% begin to talk sometime between their first and second year, and 22% begin to talk in their third year and after. With appropriate interventions, there is reason to hope that children with autism can learn to talk, at least to some extent, and non-verbal older children and adults can sometimes learn to talk or communicate in other ways.
Read More: 
https://www.autism.org/advice-for-parents/

Continue asking or input 'go back' to Main Service

column1: What are the different names and terms for autism?
column2:
Over the years, different diagnostic labels have been used, such as: autism, Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), Autism Spectrum Condition (ASC), classic autism, Kanner autism, pervasive developmental disorder (PDD), high-functioning autism (HFA), Asperger syndrome and Pathological Demand Avoidance (PDA). This reflects the different diagnostic manuals and tools used, and the different autism profiles presented by individuals. Read more:
https://www.autism.org.uk/advice-and-guidance/what-is-autism/asperger-syndrome

Continue asking or input 'go back' to Main Service

column1: What are the complications associated with Autism?
column2:
Problems with social interactions, communication and behavior can lead to:
1. Problems in school and with successful learning
2. Employment problems
3. Inability to live independently
4. Social isolation
5. Stress within the family
5. Victimization and being bullied
Read more:
https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/autism-spectrum-disorder/symptoms-causes/syc-20352928

column1: What are the complications of ASD?

5. Stress within the family
